leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: From time to time it is necessary or appropriate for a portion of a building to encroach onto an adjoining public right-of-way. Chapter 32 establishes parameters for such encroachments not only at grade but also above and below grade.
leanCodeSectionsTree.displayTitle: Chapter 32 Encroachments Into the Public Right-of-Way

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall govern the encroachment of structures into the public right-of-way.
The projection of any structure or portion thereof shall be the distance measured horizontally from the lot line to the outermost point of the projection.
The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to permit the violation of other laws or ordinances regulating the use and occupancy of public property.
Drainage water collected from a roof, awning, canopy or marquee, and condensate from mechanical equipment shall not flow over a public walking surface.

diagrams.title: Condensate Drain Pipe Materials and Reqs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Components shall be selected for the pressure and temperature rating of the installation. Joints and connections shall be made in accordance with the applicable provisions of Chapter 7 of the Plumbing Code(IPC) relative to the material type.

Condensate waste and drain line size shall be not less than 3/4-inch internal diameter and shall not decrease in size from the drain pan connection to the place of condensate disposal.

diagrams.title: Encroachments of Public Way at Steps and Awnings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the building code, architectural elements that are above grade but below 8 feet are not permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way. Steps are permitted to encroach into the right-of-way a maximum of 12 inches as long as they are guarded by either an approved device that is a minimum of 3 feet in height or they are situated between columns or pilasters. Such columns or pilasters are not permitted to project more than 12 inches into the public right-of-way either. When awnings are provided above the stairs, the vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest portion of any awning, shall be not less than 7 feet.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

children.body: Encroachments below grade shall comply with Sections 3202.1.1 through 3202.1.3.

A part of a building erected below grade that is necessary for structural support of the building or structure shall not project beyond the lot lines, except that the footings of street walls or their supports that are located not less than 8 feet (2438 mm) below grade shall not project more than 12 inches (305 mm) beyond the street lot line.
The construction and utilization of vaults and other enclosed spaces below grade shall be subject to the terms and conditions of the applicable governing authority.
Areaways shall be protected by grates, guards or other approved means.

Encroachments into the public right-of-way above grade and below 8 feet (2438 mm) in height shall be prohibited except as provided for in Sections 3202.2.1 through 3202.2.3. Doors and windows shall not open or project into the public right-of-way.

diagrams.title: Encroachment of Arch. Features at Public Way
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Architectural features, such as belt courses, lintels, sills, architraves, pediments and similar elements, that are located less than 8 feet about the ground surface of the public right-of-way, are not permitted to project more than 4 inches.

diagrams.title: Ext. Doors and the Public Way
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Windows and door are not permitted to open or project into the public right-of-way.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

diagrams.title: Encroachments of Public Way at Steps and Awnings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the building code, architectural elements that are above grade but below 8 feet are not permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way. Steps are permitted to encroach into the right-of-way a maximum of 12 inches as long as they are guarded by either an approved device that is a minimum of 3 feet in height or they are situated between columns or pilasters. Such columns or pilasters are not permitted to project more than 12 inches into the public right-of-way either. When awnings are provided above the stairs, the vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest portion of any awning, shall be not less than 7 feet.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

diagrams.title: Door Swing Direction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Doors in Group H occupancies and for egress doors serving spaces or rooms of more than 50 people are required to swing in the direction of egress travel. Other requirements such as panic or fire-exit hardware, strike-side pull clearances, intrusions on corridor widths,or intrusions into the public way should also be considered for secondary effects on the design.

children.displayTitle: 3202.2 Encroachments Above Grade and Below 8 Feet in Height
children.titleText: Encroachments Above Grade and Below 8 Feet in Height

children.body: Steps shall not project more than 12 inches (305 mm) and shall be guarded by approved devices not less than 3 feet (914 mm) in height, or shall be located between columns or pilasters.

diagrams.title: Non-Uniform Height Risers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1011.5.4.1 addresses stairway compliance when the bottom or top landing is sloped. It allows the top or bottom riser to be reduced to address the variation of the grade that the stairway needs to interface with along riser the face. Normally the minimum allowed riser height is 4", this section of code allows the riser height to be reduced to less than 4". The riser height reduction variation is limited to 8% of the stair width

diagrams.title: Encroachments of Public Way at Steps and Awnings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the building code, architectural elements that are above grade but below 8 feet are not permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way. Steps are permitted to encroach into the right-of-way a maximum of 12 inches as long as they are guarded by either an approved device that is a minimum of 3 feet in height or they are situated between columns or pilasters. Such columns or pilasters are not permitted to project more than 12 inches into the public right-of-way either. When awnings are provided above the stairs, the vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest portion of any awning, shall be not less than 7 feet.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

children.body: Columns or pilasters, including bases and moldings, shall not project more than 12 inches (305 mm). Belt courses, lintels, sills, architraves, pediments and similar architectural features shall not project more than 4 inches (102 mm).

diagrams.title: Encroachment of Arch. Features at Public Way
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Architectural features, such as belt courses, lintels, sills, architraves, pediments and similar elements, that are located less than 8 feet about the ground surface of the public right-of-way, are not permitted to project more than 4 inches.

diagrams.title: Encroachments of Public Way at Steps and Awnings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the building code, architectural elements that are above grade but below 8 feet are not permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way. Steps are permitted to encroach into the right-of-way a maximum of 12 inches as long as they are guarded by either an approved device that is a minimum of 3 feet in height or they are situated between columns or pilasters. Such columns or pilasters are not permitted to project more than 12 inches into the public right-of-way either. When awnings are provided above the stairs, the vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest portion of any awning, shall be not less than 7 feet.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

children.body: The vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest part of any awning, including valances, shall be not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).

diagrams.title: Encroachments of Public Way at Steps and Awnings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to the building code, architectural elements that are above grade but below 8 feet are not permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way. Steps are permitted to encroach into the right-of-way a maximum of 12 inches as long as they are guarded by either an approved device that is a minimum of 3 feet in height or they are situated between columns or pilasters. Such columns or pilasters are not permitted to project more than 12 inches into the public right-of-way either. When awnings are provided above the stairs, the vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest portion of any awning, shall be not less than 7 feet.

A public right-of-way, within the context of the Building Code, generally refers to areas that are designated for public use and are under the control of a public entity. These areas often include streets, sidewalks, and similar areas for pedestrian or vehicular traffic.

children.body: Encroachments 8 feet (2438 mm) or more above grade shall comply with Sections 3202.3.1 through 3202.3.4.
children.displayTitle: 3202.3 Encroachments 8 Feet or More Above Grade
children.titleText: Encroachments 8 Feet or More Above Grade

children.body: Awnings, canopies, marquees and signs shall be constructed so as to support applicable loads as specified in Chapter 16. Awnings, canopies, marquees and signs with less than 15 feet (4572 mm) of clearance above the sidewalk shall not extend into or occupy more than two-thirds the width of the sidewalk measured from the building. Stanchions or columns that support awnings, canopies, marquees and signs shall be located not less than 2 feet (610 mm) in from the curb line.

Where the vertical clearance above grade to projecting windows, balconies, architectural features or mechanical equipment is more than 8 feet (2438 mm), 1 inch (25 mm) of encroachment is permitted for each additional 1 inch (25 mm) of clearance above 8 feet (2438 mm), but the maximum encroachment shall be 4 feet (1219 mm).
children.displayTitle: 3202.3.2 Windows, Balconies, Architectural Features and Mechanical Equipment
children.titleText: Windows, Balconies, Architectural Features and Mechanical Equipment

children.body: Encroachments 15 feet (4572 mm) or more above grade shall not be limited.
children.displayTitle: 3202.3.3 Encroachments 15 Feet or More Above Grade
children.titleText: Encroachments 15 Feet or More Above Grade

children.body: The installation of a pedestrian walkway over a public right-of-way shall be subject to the approval of the applicable governing authority. The vertical clearance from the public right-of-way to the lowest part of a pedestrian walkway shall be not less than 15 feet (4572 mm).

Where allowed by the applicable governing authority, vestibules and storm enclosures shall not be erected for a period of time exceeding 7 months in any 1 year and shall not encroach more than 3 feet (914 mm) nor more than one-fourth of the width of the sidewalk beyond the street lot line. Temporary entrance awnings shall be erected with a clearance of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) to the lowest portion of the hood or awning where supported on removable steel or other approved noncombustible support.
